awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2023 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Daniel Kessler is " Selective Inference for Networks." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Washington, and the sponsoring scientist is Daniela Witten.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary scientific goal of this project was to develop selective inference methods for networks. In addition, the goal of this award was to support professional development and training for the PI in preparation for an impactful career in statistics.

Of note, the tenure period for this fellowship comprised only 10 months; it was terminated early because the PI began a position as tenure-track faculty at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he now has joint appointments in both the Department of Statistics & Operations Research and the School of Data Science and Society. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT
In collaboration with sponsoring scientist Witten and her PhD student Ethan Ancell, the PI developed methodology to support selective inference for networks. Specifically, we addressed the scenario wherein an observed network is (i) submitted to community detection (e.g., via spectral clustering), and then (ii) inference is conducted on connectivity parameters with respect to the discovered community detection. We confirmed that naive application of standard statistical tools at stage (ii) would yield invalid inference. We addressed this shortcoming by applying recent developments in both data thinning  and data fission. This enables application of essentially arbitrary community detection methodology at stage (i) followed by valid inference in stage (ii). Binary networks, which occur especially often in practice, were especially technically challenging, but we were able to apply existing statistical methodology for inference under misspecification in order to deliver valid inferential tools. This work has been presented at several venues, and the PI, Witten, and Ancell have a draft manuscript of this method that they plan to submit for publication soon, and we plan to also disseminate the method as a package in the R software environment.

During the fellowship tenure period, the PI also initiated several related projects. With sponsoring scientist Witten and her PhD student Olivia McGough, the PI developed methods to provide valid inference following "F-Screening," an especially common practice for analyses involving ANOVA. The PI also established a collaborative relationship with several neuroscientists at the University of Washington, which resulted in the application of statistical methodology for hierarchical inference to whole-brain light sheet fluorescence microscopy data. This method is now being applied to several datasets collected by lab members and will appear in future publications. In addition, the PI began collaborating with a marine biologist and NSF OCE postdoctoral research fellow Ariana Huffmyer, with the goal of adapting tools that exploit low rank structure to rich datasets collected from colonies of coral.

BROADER IMPACTS
The PI received valuable training and experience mentoring PhD students from sponsoring scientist Witten. In addition, he gave numerous invited talks and seminars during the fellowship tenure. He also played a role in organizing a webinar intended to make PhD study in statistics more broadly accessible.


Last Modified: 09/28/2024
Modified by: Daniel A Kessler
